metadata.case_name: Pipraich Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Pipraich Sugar Mills Mazdoor Union

facts.text: Appellant is a limited company carrying on business in crushing sugarcane at Pipraich in Gorakhpur District from 1932.
In 1946, appellant decided to expand business, sold old machinery (160 tons/day capacity), purchased new one (650 tons capacity), installed in 1947, started working 1948-49.
Sugar industry crisis due to shortage of sugarcane; Government assumed control of production and supply; quota allotted to appellant's mill too small for profitable working.
Appellant sustained losses in 1948-49 and 1949-50 amounting to Rs. 2,67,042-7-4.
On May 11, 1950, management wrote to Government to increase quota or permit sale of mills.
In October 1950, Government granted permission for sale of plant and machinery.
Management sold plant and machinery to Madras party; obtained lease for current season, to deliver possession on termination.
Appellant negotiating to dismantle machinery and erect at Madras for lump sum through own workmen.
Workmen, through union (respondent), hostile to sale as it would throw them out of employment; moved Government to cancel permission.
Union passed resolution on December 26, 1950, to go on strike from January 12, 1951, communicated to appellant.
On January 3, 1951, Managing Director offered 25% of profit on sale to Madras party, subject to immediate withdrawal of strike notice.
Union replied on January 5, 1951: fight with Government, not resolved; objected to terms; waiting for President Kashinath Pandey.
Management on January 8, 1951: ready to reconsider terms but insist on withdrawal of strike notice.
Kashinath Pandey discussed with management on January 9, 1951.
General Manager on January 10, 1951: accede to union points if strike notice withdrawn at once; compensation not less than a lac.
Union on January 10, 1951: waiting for Kashinath Pandey's final order; strike not coming off from 12th meantime.
No further communication; no strike; crushing continued till end of January 1951.
Lease expired end of crushing season; purchaser arrived to take delivery and dismantle.
Workmen refused to cooperate in dismantling out of sentiment.
Notice on February 28, 1951: workers to cooperate or consider discharged from March 1; 15 days notice; obstructions deprive of benefits.
Kashinath Pandey wrote to Government on March 4, 1951, threatening hunger strike if mills shifted.
Notice on March 14, 1951: workers discharged from March 1 subject to 15 days wages; take wages March 15-16.
After March 14 notice, Kashinath Pandey discussed; termination extended to March 21 pending Government decision; workmen to dismantle after.
Government on March 21, 1951, declined to interfere with sale.
Workmen declined to cooperate in dismantling from March 21; management discharged them per notices.
Purchaser entered direct agreement with workmen on April 1, 1951, for dismantling; appellant lost contract worth at least Rs. 2 lakhs profit.
Union notice on April 19, 1951, claiming 25% share of profits per Jan letters.
Appellant repudiated on June 19, 1951; referred to non-cooperation causing loss.
U.P. Government notification on November 16, 1951, under s.3 U.P. Industrial Disputes Act referring dispute: whether services terminated without settlement of due claims and improperly, and relief.

Industrial Tribunal award February 28, 1952: closure bona fide; workmen conduct unfair disentitling compensation; but Jan letters promise binding; Rs.45,000 (25% net profits) payable; notification competent despite closure.
Labour Appellate Tribunal confirmed on July 21, 1953.

legal_issues.text: Whether the notification dated November 16, 1951 under s.3 U.P. Industrial Disputes Act referring the dispute is ultra vires as industry closed and no employer-employee relation.
Whether there was a concluded and binding agreement to pay 25% of profits on sale to workmen.
Whether workmen entitled to compensation for termination on closure as retrenchment.

petitioner_arguments.text: Notification ultra vires: no industrial dispute post-closure as no existing industry or employer-employee relation; cites Indian Metal and K.N. Padmanabha Ayyar.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: U.P. Industrial Disputes Act s.3; Industrial Disputes Act s.2(k)

petitioner_arguments.text: No concluded agreement: strike notice not withdrawn; correspondence shows no acceptance; workmen non-cooperative.
Termination on closure not retrenchment; no compensation payable pre-1953 amendment.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Industrial Disputes Act s.2(oo), s.25F (no retrospective effect)

respondent_arguments.text: Promise in Jan 3 and 10 letters binding agreement; no strike occurred, continued service till discharge as consideration.
Even without agreement, compensation for retrenchment on closure; cites India Reconstruction Corp and Benett Coleman.

court_reasoning.text: Notification valid: industrial dispute if arose during existing industry, even if closed later; right accrued Jan 1951 when industry existed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Power under s.3 determined by date dispute arises, not reference date.

court_reasoning.text: No concluded agreement: offer conditional on strike withdrawal, not done; no acceptance; workmen continued hostility and non-cooperation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Correspondence lapsed without acceptance; conduct not acceptance.

court_reasoning.text: Retrenchment does not include discharge on closure; no statutory right pre-1953; tribunals' views erroneous.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Retrenchment means surplus discharge in continuing business.

holdings.text: Industrial dispute exists if arises in existing industry, even if closed before reference.
No concluded binding agreement for 25% profits.
Termination on bona fide closure not retrenchment; no compensation payable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Indian Metal and Metallurgical Corporation v. Industrial Tribunal, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Industrial dispute presupposes continued existence of industry.

precedents_cited.case_name: K. N. Padmanabha Ayyar v. The State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: No industrial dispute re closed business.

precedents_cited.case_name: Messrs Burn and Co., Ltd., Calcutta v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Labour legislation for existing industry; 1953 amendment not retrospective.

precedents_cited.case_name: J. K. Hosiery Factory v. Labour Appellate Tribunal
Employees of Messrs India Reconstruction Corporation Limited v. Messrs India Reconstruction Corporation Limited
precedents_cited.relevance: Obiter on closure as retrenchment; not applicable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Messrs Benett Coleman Company Ltd v. Their Employees

statutes_cited.name: U. P. Industrial Disputes Act XXVIII of 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers reference of industrial disputes; definition from Central Act applies.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act XIV of 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines industrial dispute, retrenchment; compensation for retrenchment.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act No. XLVIII of 1950

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; awards of Industrial Tribunal and Labour Appellate Tribunal set aside; no compensation payable to workmen as no binding agreement and closure not retrenchment.
outcome.relief_granted: None to respondent; appellant succeeds fully.

key_quotes.text: the power of the State to make a reference under section 3 will depend, not only on the dispute having arisen in an existing industry but further, on the continued existence of that industry on the date of the notification.
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner

key_quotes.text: We do not see how on this correspondence it could be held that there was a concluded agreement between the parties.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on no binding promise.

key_quotes.text: retrenchment connotes in its ordinary acceptation that the business itself is being continued but that a portion of the staff or the labour force is discharged as surplusage.
key_quotes.speaker: court
